articles.headline: Airlines Look to Limit Bumping
articles.snippet: Last year, 13 out of every 10,000 passengers were bumped on domestic flights, down from over 20.
articles.abstract: Last year, 13 out of every 10,000 passengers were bumped on domestic flights, down from over 20.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ryan Kingsbury is the rare flier who’s actually looking to be bumped from a flight.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Michelle Higgins

articles.headline: Priest Charged in U.S. Is Still Serving in India
articles.snippet: A priest charged with abusing a girl in Minnesota has been allowed to continue working at a diocese in India.
articles.abstract: A priest charged with abusing a girl in Minnesota has been allowed to continue working at a diocese in India.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Catholic priest who has been criminally charged with sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl in Minnesota six years ago is still working in his home diocese in India despite warnings to the Vatican from an American bishop that the priest continued to pose a risk to children, according to church documents made public on Monday.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Seeking a Fine of $16.4 Million Against Toyota
articles.snippet: The penalty is the largest single federal fine against an automaker and accuses Toyota of failing to notify the government about defective pedals promptly.
articles.abstract: The penalty is the largest single federal fine against an automaker and accuses Toyota of failing to notify the government about defective pedals promptly.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Transportation Department said Monday it would seek a $16.4 million fine against Toyota, the largest allowed, because the company had failed to promptly notify the government about potential problems with accelerator pedals.

articles.headline: Strong Ties With India Goal of Trip by Geithner
articles.snippet: In a two-day trip, Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is expected to focus more on infrastructure and banking issues than on trade.
articles.abstract: In a two-day trip, Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is expected to focus more on infrastructure and banking issues than on trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, arrives in New Delhi on Tuesday for a two-day trip to inaugurate a new economic and financial partnership between two of the world’s largest and oldest democracies.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Toll Mounts in West Virginia Coal Mine Explosion
articles.snippet: At least12 miners were killed and 14 were missing after an explosion ripped through a coal mine 30 miles south of Charleston.
articles.abstract: At least12 miners were killed and 14 were missing after an explosion ripped through a coal mine 30 miles south of Charleston.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 12 miners were killed and 10 were unaccounted for after an explosion ripped through a West Virginia coal mine on Monday, mining officials said.

articles.headline: Obama Limits When U.S. Would Use Nuclear Arms
articles.snippet: President Obama described his policy as part of a broader effort to edge the world toward making nuclear weapons obsolete.
articles.abstract: President Obama described his policy as part of a broader effort to edge the world toward making nuclear weapons obsolete.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Monday that he was revamping American nuclear strategy to substantially narrow the conditions under which the United States would use nuclear weapons.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Citigroup’s Chief Shrinks Company, Eyeing Growth
articles.snippet: Citigroup’s chief executive is shedding the bank’s complex businesses and shrinking its balance sheet.
articles.abstract: Citigroup’s chief executive is shedding the bank’s complex businesses and shrinking its balance sheet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup is getting smaller, and maybe even better.

articles.headline: Facing Suit, Pipe Maker Extends Guarantee
articles.snippet: JM Eagle, fighting to retain sales amid allegations that it knowingly sold defective pipe, said its guarantee will cover pipe that is already in the ground, as well as the pipe that the company will sell in the future.
articles.abstract: JM Eagle, fighting to retain sales amid allegations that it knowingly sold defective pipe, said its guarantee will cover pipe that is already in the ground, as well as the pipe that the company will sell in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: JM Eagle, fighting to retain sales amid allegations that it knowingly sold defective pipe to municipal water systems, said on Monday that it would guarantee its products for 50 years.

articles.headline: Now to Explain the Party Favors
articles.snippet: When Charles O. Prince III and Robert E. Rubin testify on Thursday about Citigroup, there is a chance to address a sense that on Wall Street, even big mistakes have no consequences.
articles.abstract: When Charles O. Prince III and Robert E. Rubin testify on Thursday about Citigroup, there is a chance to address a sense that on Wall Street, even big mistakes have no consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, two of the biggest — and among the most tarnished — names on Wall Street will testify in front of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington: Charles O. Prince III, the former chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, and Robert E. Rubin, a former top adviser and director of the bank. On the watch of these men, Citigroup lost more money than almost any company in history, requiring an extraordinary government bailout.

articles.headline: Deaths at West Virginia Mine Raise Issues About Safety
articles.snippet: The mine owner’s dismal safety record, along with several recent evacuations of the mine, left officials and miners suggesting that Monday’s explosion might have been preventable.
articles.abstract: The mine owner’s dismal safety record, along with several recent evacuations of the mine, left officials and miners suggesting that Monday’s explosion might have been preventable.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — Rescue workers began the precarious task Tuesday of removing explosive methane gas from the coal mine where at least 25 miners died the day before. The mine owner’s dismal safety record, along with several recent evacuations of the mine, left federal officials and miners suggesting that Monday’s explosion might have been preventable.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: U.S. Court Curbs F.C.C. Authority on Web Traffic
articles.snippet: A ruling would let providers slow down access to certain content and favor their services over those of competitors.
articles.abstract: A ruling would let providers slow down access to certain content and favor their services over those of competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that regulators had limited power over Web traffic under current law. The decision will allow Internet service companies to block or slow specific sites and charge video sites like YouTube to deliver their content faster to users.
